abstract: Speaking up for the champions of disclosure concerning the health of Apple’s chief executive, Steven P. Jobs.
snippet: Speaking up for the champions of disclosure concerning the health of Apple’s chief executive, Steven P. Jobs.
lead_paragraph: My friend and fellow New York Times columnist David Carr had a piece this morning arguing that there is really no need for Apple or the company’s board to disclose information about the health of its chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, because we already know everything we need to know to make an informed decision about Apple’s stock. Mr. Jobs has had cancer, a disease where, as Mr. Carr puts it, “the prognosis is always unknowable.” Then, a few months ago, while taking a leave of absence related to his health, Mr. Jobs had a liver transplant. Mr. Carr also points out — touché — that for all the talk about Mr. Jobs’s indispensability, Apple’s stock rose $50 a share while he was gone.

headline.main: Apple and Disclosure: One More Time
